NewsDetail.Author: Todd Lines
NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
Mercy or Sanity?
Managing Student Late Work

 

In my second year teaching at BYU-Idaho I ran into a dilemma.


The pre-med students that I teach need to take the Medical College Admissions Test (MCAT) early in their undergraduate experience so that they can meet medical school application deadlines.  This means that pre-med students regularly carry large credit hour loads in order to complete all of their science classes as well as their major courses.  It’s a difficult situation -- requiring students to take three or four rigorous science classes each semester for several years.  These individuals tend to be good students, but they are very busy so getting behind is almost inevitable for some.

How I initially dealt with the situation was a fantastic failure.  I was faced with students who were bright, but overscheduled.  I knew they needed experience with the material to pass the MCAT, so I wanted to be flexible with due dates. I thought of this as applying the principle of mercy to my teaching.  I made the mistake of letting a few students turn in assignments late. The trickle turned to a flood and soon the situation was out of control.  I found myself unable to handle the grading load of these late assignments because I was required to review each of them individually instead of being able to correct the work in class as groups. Additionally, students did not receive feedback in time to benefit them for the exams.  I was on campus at all hours of the day and night working on correcting assignments.  My family never saw me, and my health and church service suffered as well.  My attempt to be merciful on due dates wasn’t really helping them learn, and it was making my life miserable.  No one was happy with the situation.
One semester of this experience was enough to convince me that something had to change. I still wanted to be understanding of the students’ situation, and merciful towards them when possible regarding due dates, but not at the expense of my health or the students’ education.  I needed a new approach.

As I mulled over the dilemma, I set three criteria for the new method:

  • I wanted to be able to show mercy, but not at the expense of my family and church calling time.
  • I also wanted to be able to talk one-on-on to the students so they could learn something positive from the negative experience of having fallen behind in their work.
  • Finally, I wanted them to identify and fix the cause of the problem so they did not repeat the mistake.
For an answer, I decided to draw on my past experience as a manager of many freshly minted engineers.

It wasn’t unusual for new engineering employees to find themselves getting behind on their first projects. Their method of dealing with this was almost always to hide from their project manager until the project due date, when they just could not avoid the issue any longer. When confronted by their project manager, they generally would admit that they were very behind but would not offer a revised schedule or articulate any plan for getting the project back on track.

It took a bit of coaching to help them see that a much better approach was to notify the project manager well in advance of the due date that there was likely a schedule problem.  At the same time they identified the potential problem, they needed to approach the project manager with a plan for how to accomplish the required work and with an estimate of what additional resources (more time, help from other employees, better tools, etc.) would be required.

This method offered the supervisor a choice between several options:
  • Come up with his/her own plan
  • Find someone else to do the job and start over
  • Accept the employee’s plan
Generally if the employee had analyzed the situation well, s/he had some idea what it would take to do the job. The project manager rarely had extra people that could be asked to take the project and start from scratch, nor did s/he usually want to come up with his/her own plan, so the project manager was highly motivated to accept a reasonable proposal. Working with the employee’s proposed revisions for the job was usually the best way to get the job done.

In the case of those new engineers who followed this procedure, I observed several important improvements:
  • The job got done
  • The employee suffered less personal cost
  • Both the supervisor and the employee were happier at performance review time
I thought I might be able to apply a similar strategy to my problem with students getting behind. My hope was that if successful, this would not only solve my problem with late assignments, but would also teach a strategy to the students for use in similar situations they might face later in life. My hope was that these students would not have to learn this lesson as new, young employees when their family’s livelihood might depend on the outcome.

So here’s what I tried: I developed a one-page contract that my students can fill out and present to me when they get behind. The contract requires the student to state what work they will do, set a due date, and assign a percentage of the original grade that will be applied to the late work. This must be done before they approach me about the problem. The contract also requires the student to build a plan for changing their behavior so they will not get behind in the future.  Because I want them to form this plan, I don’t accept late homework without the contract, and I generally don’t accept the contract if the student has already done the late work.  (There is already a standard penalty for late work in my syllabus that covers situations where the student just turns in something late without talking to me in advance. It is a 50% reduction in value per lecture day.)
The student brings their draft contract to me and we discuss it. Generally I end up sending them away to revise the contract because they have given little thought to how they will change so the lateness problem does not recur. I don’t want them saving their grade in my class at the expense of another class, so a good plan is important if the student’s underlying problem is to be resolved. By the time students develop and propose a plan in the contract, and come to my office to talk with me about it, the process has defined a way for me to show some mercy to students in a difficult situation, but at the same time insure that the student will not need more mercy in the future.
So far this has been much more successful than my first attempt.  There are still details to work out in the system. For example, I have learned that allowing a student to negotiate too high a percentage for the late work is not good, but too little is not motivating enough to convince them to go through the difficult process of planning how to catch up and stay on top of their assignments.  Only time will tell if this approach is successful in preparing students for their future careers, but so far I have been much happier, less stressed, and my family no longer comments on how much I’ve changed since they last saw me.
